name: Appeal to Authority
definition: Arguing something is true because an authority figure believes it, without presenting actual evidence.
example: "It must be true—Dr. Smith said so, and she's a scientist."

name: Appeal to Ignorance
definition: Claiming something is true because it hasn't been proven false, or vice versa.
example: "No one has proven aliens don’t exist, so they must be real."

name: Appeal to Pity
definition: Attempting to persuade using emotion—specifically sympathy—rather than valid logic.
example: "You should give me an A—if I fail this class, I’ll lose my scholarship."

name: Appeal to Emotion
definition: Manipulating an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
example: "If you care about your children, you’ll support this new policy."

name: Straw Man Fallacy
definition: Misrepresenting or exaggerating someone’s argument to make it easier to attack.
example: "She wants to reduce military spending—clearly, she wants to leave us defenseless."

name: Slippery Slope Fallacy
definition: Arguing that one small step will inevitably lead to a chain of related (negative) events.
example: "If we allow students to redo assignments, soon they’ll expect to retake entire classes."

name: Genetic Fallacy
definition: Judging something as good or bad based on its origin rather than its current meaning or context.
example: "That idea came from a corrupt politician, so it must be wrong."

name: False Dilemma
definition: Presenting only two choices when more options exist.
example: "You’re either with us or against us."

name: Causation Fallacy
definition: Assuming that because two things occur together, one caused the other.
example: "Since I started wearing these socks, I haven’t lost a game—so they must be lucky."

name: Equivocation
definition: Using ambiguous language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.
example: "A feather is light. What is light cannot be dark. So a feather cannot be dark."

name: Hasty Generalizations
definition: Drawing a conclusion based on insufficient or non-representative evidence.
example: "I met two rude New Yorkers, so all New Yorkers must be rude."
